hints_html:
The market equilibrium is defined to be the intersection point of the graphs of the demand function and the supply functions.

If \(D(q)\) denotes the demand function as a function in the quantity \(q\) and if the market equilibrium is given by the point \((q_e,p_e)\), then the consumer surplus is given by the formula

\[\begin{aligned} \int_0^{q_e} \left(D(q) - p_e\right) \, dq\end{aligned}\]

See the wikipedia page on Economic surplus for more information about the market equilibrium and the consumer surplus.

sols_html:
Let us write the supply and demand function as functions in the price \(p\). The text says that at a price \(p\) the supplier produces \(p-2\) units. Thus, the supply function must be

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle p = S(q) = q + 2\end{aligned}\]

At a price \(p\) the consumer demands \(65/p - 10\) units. In terms of the demand function this translates into

\[\begin{aligned} p = D(q) = \frac{65}{q+10}\end{aligned}\]

By definition, the market equilibrium is the intersection point of the graph of \(S(q)\) and \(D(q)\). Let us denote this point by \((q_e,p_e)\). To compute that point, we set both functions equal and compute a solution for \(q\):

\[\begin{aligned} S(q) &= D(q) \\ q + 2 &= \frac{65}{q+10}\end{aligned}\]

And rearranging we obtain the equation

\[\begin{aligned} (q+2)(q+10) &= 65 \\ q^2 + 12q - 45 &= 0\end{aligned}\]

This is a quadratic equation and can be solved with the help of the \(abc\)-formula: the solutions to a quadratic equation of the form \(ax^2 + bx + c = 0\) are given by

\[\begin{aligned} x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}\end{aligned}\]

Note, that in our problem the variable \(x\) is replaced by the variable \(q\) and we have \(a = 1\), \(b = 12\) and \(x = -45\). Hence,

\[\begin{aligned} q = \frac{-12 \pm \sqrt{144 + 180}}{2} = -6 \pm 9\end{aligned}\]

The solution \(-6 - 9\) is not feasible, because quantities are always nonnegative. Hence, we arrive at the unique solution \(q_e = -6 + 9 = 3\). We can calculate the associated price by using \(D(q)\) or \(S(q)\). Since \(S(q)\) looks simpler than \(D(q)\) we use \(S(q)\) and get \(p = S(q_e) = S(3) = 3 + 2 = 5\). Note, that this price is in between the range given in the problem. Let us summarize:

The market equilibrium is attained at \((q_e,p_e) = (3,5)\)

The second part of the question asks us to compute the consumer surplus. By definition, the consumer surplus is given by the formula

\[\begin{aligned} \text{consumer surplus} = \int_0^{q_e} (D(q) - p_e)\, dq\end{aligned}\]

The following steps compute this integral:

\[\begin{aligned} \int_0^{q_e} (D(q) - p_e)\, dq &= \int_0^3 \left(\frac{65}{q+10} - 5\right) \, dq \\ &= 65\int_0^3 \frac{1}{q+10} \, dq - \int_0^3 5\, dq \\ &= 65\ln(q+10)\Bigr|_0^3 - 5q\Bigr|_0^3 \\ &= 65(\ln(13) - \ln(10)) - 15 \\ &= 65\ln(13/10) - 15 \\ &\approx 2.05\end{aligned}\]

The consumer surplus is approximately \$2.05

statement_html: The unit price of a certain commodity can fluctuate anywhere between \$2 and \$6.50. If the unit price is \(\$p\), the supplier produces \((p-2)\) units of it, while the consumers demand \(65p^{-1} - 10\) units. Find the market equilibrium and the consumer surplus.
